metadata.title: ALS Care & Support India - Comprehensive FAQ
sources: ALS Care & Support India WhatsApp Community (2021-2025)
metadata.disclaimer: This FAQ is compiled from experiences shared by caregivers and patients in the ALS Care & Support India community representing 10+ years of collective wisdom from 650+ families. It is intended for educational purposes only and does NOT constitute medical advice. Every ALS patient's condition is unique. Always consult your neurologist, pulmonologist, or treating physician before making any medical decisions.

categories.name: Getting Started with ALS Care
categories.description: First steps after diagnosis, building care teams, and understanding the basics

questions.question: My loved one was just diagnosed with ALS. We are completely lost. Where do we even start?
questions.answer:
**Take a deep breath.** Many families in our community were in the same place. Here's what helped them get organized:

**Week 1 Priorities:**

1. **Join a support community** - Introduce yourself, mention your city, current symptoms, and stage. The community will guide based on your specific situation.

2. **Get baseline assessments done:**
   â€¢ FVC (lung function test) - critical for respiratory planning
   â€¢ Swallowing assessment
   â€¢ Overall strength evaluation

3. **Start researching equipment NOW** - Even if you don't need it today. When you need a BiPAP at 2 AM urgently, you don't want to be searching for vendors.

4. **Involve your PALS in all decisions** - Many patients feel they've lost control. Keeping them involved helps emotionally.

5. **Don't Google too much initially** - It will scare you with worst-case scenarios. Real families have PALS living 5, 8, even 10+ years with good care.
questions.recommendation: Focus on quality of life, not statistics. Every patient is different.

questions.question: What do PALS and CALS mean?
questions.answer:
These are terms commonly used in the ALS community worldwide:

**PALS** = Person/Patient with ALS (the patient themselves)
**CALS** = Caregiver of person with ALS (family members, hired help)

We use these terms because they're shorter to type and also remind us that the patient is a PERSON first, not just a 'patient' or 'case'.

questions.question: How do I know what stage my PALS is at?
questions.answer:
Here's how we typically think about stages based on practical care needs:

**Early Stage:**
â€¢ Can walk (maybe with support)
â€¢ Can eat normally or with minor difficulty
â€¢ Can breathe on own, SpOâ‚‚ stays above 95%
â€¢ Needs help with some activities but mostly independent

**Middle Stage:**
â€¢ Wheelchair dependent or very limited walking
â€¢ Eating takes longer (30-45+ minutes), some choking
â€¢ May need BiPAP at night, SpOâ‚‚ drops sometimes
â€¢ Speech becoming unclear

**Advanced Stage:**
â€¢ Bed-bound or fully wheelchair dependent
â€¢ On feeding tube (PEG/Ryles)
â€¢ BiPAP most of the day or on tracheostomy
â€¢ Needs 24/7 care for everything

**Important:** Staging is less important than watching for specific warning signs that tell you when to act.

categories.name: Breathing Support & BiPAP
categories.description: Critical respiratory support, BiPAP usage, ventilator settings, and when to act

questions.question: When does a PALS need BiPAP support and what are the signs?
questions.answer:
**Key Understanding:** In ALS, the problem is NOT oxygen getting in, but COâ‚‚ (carbon dioxide) getting OUT. When breathing muscles weaken, COâ‚‚ builds up in the blood. Plain oxygen can mask this problem - SpOâ‚‚ may look normal while COâ‚‚ reaches dangerous levels.

**BiPAP works differently:** It pushes air in (helps oxygen) AND helps push COâ‚‚ out by supporting the breathing muscles.

**DEFINITE SIGNS (act immediately):**
â€¢ Cannot lie flat - needs 2-3 pillows or sleeps in recliner (orthopnea)
â€¢ Waking up with headaches (COâ‚‚ building up at night)
â€¢ SpOâ‚‚ dropping below 94% at any time
â€¢ Feeling breathless at rest or while talking

**EARLY WARNING SIGNS (start planning):**
â€¢ More tired than usual, sleeping more during day
â€¢ Morning grogginess that doesn't go away
â€¢ Difficulty completing long sentences without pausing
â€¢ Yawning frequently (body trying to get more oxygen)
â€¢ Weak cough - can't clear throat properly

**Oxygen Only vs BiPAP:**
| Aspect | Oxygen Only | BiPAP |
|--------|-------------|-------|
| Increases Oâ‚‚ | Yes | Yes |
| Removes COâ‚‚ | NO | YES |
| Supports breathing muscles | NO | YES |
| Safe for ALS alone | RISKY | RECOMMENDED |
questions.warning: Several families delayed BiPAP and ended up with emergency tracheostomies. Those who started early are often still on BiPAP years later with good quality of life.
questions.recommendation: If you see these signs, consult your pulmonologist about starting BiPAP early. Don't wait!

questions.question: Doctor said SpO2 is 96% so no BiPAP needed. But he can't sleep flat and gets breathless. Should we wait?
questions.answer:
**NO, don't wait!** This is a common mistake.

**Why these signs matter:**
â€¢ Can't sleep flat (orthopnea) = earliest sign of diaphragm weakness
â€¢ Breathlessness with activity = respiratory muscles struggling

**The Hidden Problem:** Daytime SpOâ‚‚ may be fine, but it drops significantly at night when diaphragm works harder. Many PALS have normal daytime readings but drop to 85-88% during sleep.

**What to do:**
1. Get overnight pulse oximetry or sleep study
2. If SpOâ‚‚ drops below 93-94% at night, push for BiPAP
3. Buy a good pulse oximeter (â‚¹1,500-3,000) for home monitoring

if_then.then: Immediate BiPAP evaluation needed - don't delay

if_then.if: Only slight fatigue with normal SpOâ‚‚
if_then.then: Discuss with pulmonologist - may not be urgent yet but start preparing

questions.warning: SpOâ‚‚ of 96% during day means nothing - it drops at night. Many PALS have normal daytime SpOâ‚‚ but drop to 85-88% at night.

questions.question: Which BiPAP machine should I buy? What are the options and costs in India?
questions.answer:
**For ALS patients, machines with volume-assured modes (AVAPS/iVAPS) are recommended** because they adapt as the disease progresses.

**Recommended Machines:**

| Machine | Approx. Cost | Notes |
|---------|--------------|-------|
| ResMed Stellar 150 | â‚¹3.0 lakhs | iVAPS mode, works with tracheostomy, built-in battery. Most popular in community. |
| Philips Trilogy 100 | â‚¹4.5 lakhs | Versatile, portable, AVAPS-AE mode. Excellent for invasive/non-invasive. |
| Philips DreamStation AVAPS | â‚¹1.0 lakh | Good budget option with AVAPS mode. May need Whisper Swivel for tracheostomy. |
| ResMed Lumis 150 | â‚¹1.5-1.8 lakhs | Same iVAPS mode as Stellar, slightly fewer features. Good budget option. |

if_then.if: Planning for long-term home care with possible tracheostomy
if_then.then: Consider Stellar 150 or Trilogy 100 from the start
Start with DreamStation AVAPS, plan upgrade later

questions.recommendation: Buy from authorized dealers only. Get proper training. MOST IMPORTANTLY - buy a second backup machine (can be used/refurbished for â‚¹60-80k). When your main machine fails at 3 AM, you'll thank yourself.

questions.question: What's the difference between S/T mode, AVAPS, and iVAPS?
questions.answer:
**S/T MODE (Spontaneous/Timed):**
â€¢ You set a fixed pressure (e.g., IPAP 14, EPAP 6)
â€¢ Machine gives same pressure for every breath
â€¢ Problem: As ALS progresses and muscles weaken, fixed pressure may not be enough
â€¢ You have to keep manually increasing settings

**AVAPS MODE (Philips machines):**
â€¢ You set a TARGET volume (e.g., 400ml per breath)
â€¢ Machine automatically adjusts pressure to achieve this target
â€¢ Much better for ALS because it adapts to changing needs

**iVAPS MODE (ResMed machines):**
â€¢ Same concept as AVAPS
â€¢ Has extra smart features like learning patient's breathing pattern

**Best Analogy:** S/T is like setting AC to blow at fixed speed. AVAPS/iVAPS is like setting AC to maintain room at 24Â°C - it adjusts automatically to achieve the goal.
questions.recommendation: AVAPS or iVAPS is much better for ALS because the machine adapts as disease progresses.

questions.question: What BiPAP settings should we start with?
questions.answer:
**Recommended starting settings for iVAPS/AVAPS mode** (always confirm with your pulmonologist):

â€¢ **Mode:** iVAPS or AVAPS
â€¢ **Height:** Enter patient's height (machine calculates target volume from this)
â€¢ **Tidal Volume:** Approximately 7 Ã— weight in kg (e.g., 60 kg patient = ~420ml)
â€¢ **EPAP:** 5-6 cm Hâ‚‚O
â€¢ **PS Min/IPAP Min:** 4 cm Hâ‚‚O
â€¢ **PS Max/IPAP Max:** 12-14 cm Hâ‚‚O (can increase later if needed)
â€¢ **Target Rate/BPM:** 15 breaths/minute
â€¢ **Rise Time:** 200-300ms (increase to 300ms if pressure rise feels too fast)

if_then.then: Check mask fit, circuit connections, or cuff inflation
Gradually increase IPAP Max by 1-2 cm Hâ‚‚O

questions.recommendation: For first few days, use during daytime while watching TV to get used to it. Don't start at night - it's harder to adapt when you're trying to sleep.

questions.question: Should we use oxygen concentrator with BiPAP?
questions.answer:
**Critical Warning:** Plain oxygen ALONE should NEVER be used for ALS patients!

**Why It's Dangerous:** In ALS, the problem is weak breathing muscles, not lack of oxygen. Plain oxygen:
â€¢ Masks the real problem
â€¢ Causes COâ‚‚ retention (can be fatal)
â€¢ Reduces body's natural drive to breathe

**When Oâ‚‚ CAN Be Used:**
â€¢ ONLY with BiPAP, never alone
â€¢ During infections when SpOâ‚‚ remains low despite BiPAP
â€¢ As advised by pulmonologist

**How to Connect:** Use oxygen enrichment port on ventilator/BiPAP - NOT directly to patient. Flow rate: Typically 1-2 LPM.

if_then.then: First check secretions, settings, circuit. Only add Oâ‚‚ if still needed.
Always use WITH BiPAP, never alone for ALS patients

categories.name: Tracheostomy Care
categories.description: When to consider tracheostomy, daily care, suctioning, and managing complications

questions.question: Doctor is recommending tracheostomy. How do we decide if it's time?
questions.answer:
**Signs that it may be time:**
â€¢ BiPAP 20+ hours daily and still having SpOâ‚‚ drops
â€¢ Frequent desaturation even with BiPAP optimized
â€¢ Secretions that can't be managed with oral/nasal suction
â€¢ Repeated chest infections/aspiration
â€¢ COâ‚‚ levels staying high (check ABG)

**Important considerations:**

1. **PLANNED vs EMERGENCY:** Planned tracheostomy with time to prepare is SO much better than emergency tracheostomy during a crisis.

2. **QUALITY OF LIFE:** Many PALS on trach have BETTER quality of life - no mask on face, can eat more easily (sometimes), more stable breathing.

3. **PATIENT'S CHOICE:** Most importantly - what does your PALS want? This should be THEIR decision.

4. **CARE REQUIREMENTS:** Trach requires regular suctioning, tube changes, 24/7 trained caregiver. Ensure this can be arranged before proceeding.
perspectives: We were terrified of tracheostomy. But after 2 emergency admissions in one month, we did planned trach. It's been 2 years now. My husband is stable. I wish we'd done it sooner.
My mother chose not to have tracheostomy. We respected her decision. She passed peacefully at home. There's no wrong answer.
questions.warning: Whatever you decide, do NOT let it become an emergency decision. If leaning towards trach, plan it. If declining trach, ensure palliative care is in place.

questions.question: How do I suction properly without hurting my PALS?
questions.answer:
**GATHER EVERYTHING BEFORE STARTING:**
â€¢ Suction machine (pressure set to 100-120 mmHg)
â€¢ Suction catheters (Fr 12 is common for size 7-7.5 tube)
â€¢ Normal saline 2ml vials
â€¢ Ambu bag connected and ready
â€¢ Gloves, tissues/gauze

**THE PROCEDURE:**
1. Wash hands well, wear gloves
2. Pour 1ml Normal Saline into the trach tube (directly into the hole). This loosens secretions. Patient may cough - that's normal!
3. Connect Ambu bag and give 4-5 gentle squeezes. This pushes the saline around and brings up secretions.
4. Turn on suction machine. Disconnect from ventilator/BiPAP.
5. Insert suction catheter into trach tube - DON'T apply suction while going in.
6. NOW apply suction (thumb on hole) and slowly withdraw while rotating. Takes about 8-10 seconds.
7. Immediately reconnect to BiPAP/ventilator.
8. Let patient rest 30-60 seconds. Repeat if needed.

**WATCH OUT FOR:**
â€¢ SpOâ‚‚ dropping below 85% - stop and connect to Ambu immediately
â€¢ Catheter not going in - don't force, try smaller size
â€¢ Lots of blood - stop, call doctor
questions.recommendation: First 10 times will be scary. By 50th time, you'll do it without thinking. The whole procedure takes 90 seconds once you're comfortable!

questions.question: How many times a day should I suction?
questions.answer:
**ROUTINE SUCTIONING (even if no obvious need):**
â€¢ Morning after waking up
â€¢ Before each major feed
â€¢ Before sleep at night
â€¢ Minimum 4-5 times per day

**SUCTION IMMEDIATELY WHEN YOU SEE/HEAR:**
â€¢ Gurgling or rattling sound when breathing
â€¢ SpOâ‚‚ dropping for no clear reason
â€¢ Patient looking uncomfortable, restless
â€¢ Visible secretions at trach opening

**During infections:** May need 8-12 times daily

if_then.if: Frequent blood-tinged secretions or patient very irritated
if_then.then: Over-suctioning - reduce frequency, use gentler technique

if_then.if: Constant gurgling, frequent SpOâ‚‚ drops, secretions bubbling out

questions.recommendation: Better to suction more frequently with less aggressive technique than to wait until there's a huge mucus plug.

categories.name: Feeding & Nutrition
categories.description: PEG tube placement, feeding protocols, managing blockages, and nutritional guidance

questions.question: My PALS is taking 1.5 hours to finish one meal and coughing throughout. Should we consider a feeding tube?
questions.answer:
**This is a situation many families face.** Here's what has worked for others:

**UNDERSTAND THEIR FEAR:**
â€¢ They see it as 'giving up'
â€¢ Fear of surgery (for PEG)
â€¢ Loss of pleasure of eating

**HOW TO APPROACH THE CONVERSATION:**

1. **Reframe the purpose:** It's not about STOPPING oral eating. It's about getting nutrition without exhaustion. They can STILL taste food if they want - small amounts for pleasure.

2. **Address specific fears:** PEG surgery is minor - 15-20 minute procedure. Tube is hidden under clothes.

3. **Involve them in decisions:** Let them choose when, which hospital, etc.

**RISK OF WAITING:**
â€¢ 1.5 hours for a meal = extreme exhaustion
â€¢ Coughing = aspiration risk = pneumonia
â€¢ Each pneumonia episode weakens further
â€¢ Emergency tube insertion is harder than planned
questions.warning: If meals taking 1+ hours with frequent choking, the risk of aspiration pneumonia is significant. Don't delay too long.

questions.question: What's better - PEG tube or Ryles (NG) tube?
questions.answer:
**PEG is MUCH better for long-term use.** Here's why:

| Aspect | Ryles (NG) Tube | PEG Tube |
|--------|-----------------|----------|
| Location | Through nose into stomach | Through abdomen into stomach |
| Visibility | Visible on face | Hidden under clothes |
| Comfort | Can irritate nose/throat | Much more comfortable |
| Duration | Change every 2-3 months | Lasts 6-12 months |
| BiPAP compatibility | Creates leak with mask | No interference |
| Cost | â‚¹500-2,000 | â‚¹15,000-40,000 |
questions.recommendation: If tube feeding needed for more than a few weeks, go straight to PEG. Don't waste time with Ryles.

questions.question: PEG tube got blocked completely. What do I do?
questions.answer:
**Don't panic!** Try these in order:

1. **WARM WATER FLUSH:** Fill 50ml syringe with warm (not hot) water. Push gently.

2. **THE COLA TRICK:** Yes, seriously! Clamp the tube, fill with Coca-Cola or similar carbonated drink, leave for 30-60 minutes, then try flushing with water. The acid and fizz break down the blockage.

3. **ENZYME SOLUTION:** Ask pharmacist for pancreatic enzyme powder. Mix with water, inject into tube, wait 30 min, flush.

4. **MECHANICAL CLEANING:** Get PEG tube cleaning brush from Amazon (â‚¹99). Gently insert and rotate.

**HOW TO PREVENT BLOCKAGES:**
â€¢ Flush 30-50ml water BEFORE every feed
â€¢ Flush 70-100ml water AFTER every feed (most important!)
â€¢ Don't give very thick feeds - thin them down
â€¢ Crush medications very finely, use liquid medications when possible

questions.question: How much and how often should we feed through PEG?
questions.answer:
**General Guidelines:**
â€¢ Feed per meal: 150-250ml
â€¢ Total daily: 1500-2000ml across 6-8 feeds
â€¢ Feed duration: Slow over 15-20 minutes (not bolus)

**Sample Schedule:** 7am, 10am, 1pm, 4pm, 7pm, 10pm

**Critical Steps:**
â€¢ Flush with 30ml water BEFORE feeding
â€¢ Flush with 50-70ml water AFTER feeding
â€¢ Keep bed elevated 30-45Â° during and 30-40 minutes after

**Feed Consistency:** Smooth, no lumps. Use high-speed blender.

**Protein Needs:** 1-1.5g per kg body weight daily. Add whey protein isolate if needed.

if_then.then: Reduce quantity per feed, increase frequency, check for acid reflux
Add more fiber, ensure adequate water, consider laxatives

categories.name: Essential Equipment Guide
categories.description: Essential equipment, power backup, and home ICU setup guidance with India-specific costs

questions.question: What basic monitoring and respiratory equipment do I need?
questions.answer:
**MONITORING (Essential):**

â€¢ **Pulse Oximeter** - â‚¹1,500-3,000
  Measures SpOâ‚‚ and pulse. Normal SpOâ‚‚: 95-99%. Below 90% needs intervention.

â€¢ **Ambu Bag** - â‚¹2,000 (MUST HAVE 2-3)
  Manual resuscitation for emergencies. Use when BiPAP fails or during power outages.

**RESPIRATORY:**

â€¢ **Suction Machine** - â‚¹6,000-8,000 (Yuwell recommended)
  Essential for tracheostomy, useful even before. Set pressure to 100-120 mmHg.

â€¢ **Nebulizer Machine** - â‚¹1,500-3,000
  Delivers medication to lungs. Common: Duolin, Budecort, NS, Mucinac.

â€¢ **Cough Assist Machine** - ~â‚¹2 lakhs
  Helps clear phlegm. Models: T70 (basic) vs E70 (advanced).
questions.warning: Have BACKUP equipment for BiPAP, suction, and nebulizer. Equipment failure during emergency can be life-threatening.

questions.question: What power backup do I need for BiPAP and other equipment?
questions.answer:
**Power backup is CRITICAL. Without it, a power cut can be life-threatening.**

**HOME BACKUP:**
â€¢ Standard home inverter (e.g., Luminous) with adequate battery
â€¢ Calculate: BiPAP uses 50-100W, suction ~100W, nebulizer ~50W
â€¢ Ensure inverter can handle total load + buffer

**Equipment Backup Costs:**
| Equipment | Cost | Purpose |
|-----------|------|----------|
| Home Inverter (2KVA min) | â‚¹15,000-30,000 | 4-6 hours backup |
| Generator (2-3 KVA) | â‚¹25,000-50,000 | Extended outages |
| Portable Battery Pack | â‚¹15,000-25,000 | Short outages/travel |
| Ambu Bag | â‚¹2,000 | Manual backup - no power needed |
| Oxygen Cylinder | â‚¹5,000-8,000 | Concentrator needs power |
questions.recommendation: Apply for essential/medical connection from electricity board. Medical connections get priority restoration.

categories.name: Emergency Protocols
categories.description: What to do in emergency situations - SpO2 drops, power failure, equipment failure

questions.question: SpO2 is dropping! What do I do?
questions.answer:
**IMMEDIATE Steps:**

1. **Give Ambu bag immediately** - provides instant relief

2. **Ask PALS** (if able) where they feel blockage - chest, throat, or balloon area

3. **Check ventilator** for disconnections or kinks

4. **If wet secretions:** NS 1-2ml + Ambu 5-6 pumps + Suction

5. **If dry cough:** Start nebulization with Levolin, continue Ambu support

6. **Tracheostomy patients:** Always do subglottic port suction

7. **Repeat cycle:** Ambu â†’ Suction â†’ Check SpOâ‚‚ until >94%

if_then.then: Continue aggressive Ambu + Suction, consider calling emergency
Nebulize with Inhalex or Mucinac to thin them
2ml NS + 8-10 firm Ambu squeezes, may need tube change

questions.warning: SpOâ‚‚ below 85% for more than 2-3 minutes despite intervention - call for medical help immediately!

questions.question: Power cut at night! BiPAP stopped. What's the emergency plan?
questions.answer:
**Immediate Actions:**

1. **Start manual Ambu bagging** if PALS on 24/7 ventilation
2. Check inverter - is it working? Battery may have died
3. Keep PALS sitting up (not lying flat)
4. Monitor SpOâ‚‚

**Proper Setup You MUST Have:**
â€¢ Home Inverter (2KVA minimum) - 4-6 hours backup
â€¢ Generator contact for extended outages
â€¢ Portable Battery Pack for travel
â€¢ Ambu Bag - no power needed
â€¢ Oxygen Cylinder - concentrator needs power, cylinder doesn't
questions.warning: Everyone in household should know how to use Ambu bag!

questions.question: What is the Ambu bag and how do we use it?
questions.answer:
**What It Is:** Manual resuscitator - your most important emergency tool. Provides breaths when ventilator is insufficient.

**How to Use:**
1. Connect to ventilator circuit (ventilator keeps running)
2. Squeeze slowly and steadily - mimics natural breath
3. Release to allow exhalation
4. Rhythm: 12-15 squeezes per minute

**When to Use Ambu:**
â€¢ SpOâ‚‚ dropping
â€¢ Before and after suction
â€¢ PALS feeling breathless
â€¢ High pulse/BP from respiratory discomfort
â€¢ Ventilator seems insufficient
â€¢ During nebulization if struggling

**Must Have:** At least 2 Ambu bags as backup. Cost: ~â‚¹2,000
questions.recommendation: When parameters are unstable and you're unsure what's wrong, give Ambu for 1 minute. It often provides quick relief and gives you time to assess.

categories.name: Daily Care & Comfort
categories.description: Bedsores, secretions, constipation, and routine comfort care

questions.question: How do we manage constipation?
questions.answer:
**Constipation is very common in ALS** due to reduced mobility and medications. Here's a proven protocol:

**1. DIETARY CHANGES (First Step):**
â€¢ High fiber foods: Papaya, pears, apple, spinach, bottle gourd
â€¢ Add flax seed powder to feeds
â€¢ Adequate fluid intake

**2. STOOL SOFTENERS:**
â€¢ PEG (Movicol/Polyethylene Glycol): 17gm in water daily
â€¢ Pruvict 2mg tablet with PEG

**3. IF STILL CONSTIPATED (Day 3):**
â€¢ Piclin syrup 10ml OR Cremalax 5-10mg tablet
â€¢ Glycerine suppository if needed

**4. LAST RESORT:**
â€¢ Glycerine enema (safe)
â€¢ Sodium phosphate enema only if absolutely necessary (can cause electrolyte imbalance)

questions.question: How do we prevent and treat bed sores?
questions.answer:
**PREVENTION (Most Important):**
â€¢ Position changes every 2-3 hours
â€¢ Use air mattress (Romsons Cell Mat or similar)
â€¢ Keep skin clean and dry
â€¢ Use pillows for proper positioning
â€¢ Apply coconut oil on pressure points
â€¢ Use Abzorb powder for mild sores

**High-Risk Areas:** Tailbone, heels, back of head, shoulders, elbows

**FOR EXISTING SORES:**
â€¢ Stage 1 (Red skin): More position changes, air exposure, coconut oil
â€¢ Stage 2-3 (Open wound): Clean with NS and betadine, Cuticell gauze
â€¢ Consult doctor if sores are deep or infected
questions.warning: Deep wounds, signs of infection (pus, redness, swelling), bone visible - seek immediate medical help

questions.question: What can help with excess saliva (sialorrhea)?
questions.answer:
**Options for managing excess saliva:**

â€¢ **Glycopyrrolate (1-2mg):** Start with small dose (1mg). Watch for side effect - can dry out chest and thicken phlegm.

â€¢ **Atropine drops:** Under tongue, helps reduce saliva

â€¢ **Botox injections:** Into salivary glands, longer lasting effect

â€¢ **Suction:** Keep suction ready for managing excess saliva
questions.warning: Drying medications can thicken mucus in the lungs, making it harder to clear. Balance is key - managing excess saliva is better than completely drying it out.

categories.name: Medications & Supplements
categories.description: Common medications, supplements, and vaccinations for ALS patients

questions.question: What is Riluzole and should my PALS take it?
questions.answer:
**Riluzole (Rilutor/Reluzole)** is the only FDA-approved drug that has been shown to modestly slow ALS progression.

**How it works:** Reduces glutamate toxicity (a neurotransmitter that can damage nerve cells)

**Dosage:** Usually 50mg twice daily

**Side effects:** Some experience dizziness initially (usually improves in 1-2 weeks), nausea, fatigue

**Community experience:** Many take it continuously for years. Those who experienced dizziness often found it resolved. Some stopped due to side effects.

if_then.then: Try reducing to once daily temporarily, then gradually increase

questions.recommendation: Consult your neurologist before making any changes to Riluzole dosage.

questions.question: What other medications might help?
questions.answer:
**Common medications used** (always consult your doctor):

**FOR MUSCLE CRAMPS/SPASTICITY:**
â€¢ Baclofen, Tizanidine
â€¢ Gabapentin (also helps with pain)

**FOR PSEUDOBULBAR AFFECT (uncontrolled laughing/crying):**
â€¢ Nuedexta

**FOR SECRETION MANAGEMENT:**
â€¢ Mucinac 600 (thins mucus)
â€¢ Glycopyrrolate (reduces saliva - use cautiously)

**FOR GASTRIC ISSUES:**
â€¢ Acogut (for acid reflux - works well per community)
â€¢ Sompraz IT / Nexpro IT (with itopride for better results)

**FOR INFECTIONS:**
â€¢ Antibiotics targeting Pseudomonas (common in trach patients): Levofloxacin, Ofloxacin, Ciprofloxacin
â€¢ Always do sputum culture to identify specific bacteria
questions.warning: All prescription medications should only be taken as advised by treating physician.

questions.question: What vaccinations should PALS get?
questions.answer:
**Recommended Vaccinations:**

1. **Influvac Tetra:** Annual flu vaccine - important as flu can be serious for ventilator-dependent patients

2. **Prevnar 13:** Pneumococcal vaccine (13-strain)

3. **Pneumococcal 23:** Another pneumococcal vaccine

**Purpose:** Prevents serious respiratory infections that can be life-threatening for ALS patients.

**Timing:** Discuss with doctor. Usually given when patient is stable, not during active infection.

categories.name: Caregiver Support & Well-being
categories.description: Preventing burnout, managing stress, training staff, and getting support

questions.question: I'm exhausted from caregiving. How do others cope?
questions.answer:
**Caregiver burnout is real and serious.** Here's what has helped others:

**1. BUILD A CARE TEAM:**
â€¢ Hire trained nursing staff if possible
â€¢ Rotate family members for different shifts
â€¢ Train backup caregivers for all critical tasks

**2. TAKE BREAKS:**
â€¢ Even 30 minutes of personal time daily helps
â€¢ Arrange respite care for longer breaks

**3. CONNECT WITH COMMUNITY:**
â€¢ Join support groups (WhatsApp, Facebook)
â€¢ Share experiences with others who understand

**4. SEEK HELP WHEN NEEDED:**
â€¢ Don't hesitate to see a counselor or psychologist
â€¢ Antidepressants may help if feeling overwhelmed
perspectives: You cannot pour from an empty cup
Taking care of yourself IS taking care of your PALS
questions.warning: Persistent depression, anxiety, or inability to cope - seek professional help immediately

questions.question: How do we keep our PALS mentally engaged and positive?
questions.answer:
**Keeping quality of life high:**

â€¢ **Involve them in decisions:** About their care, daily routine, family matters

â€¢ **Enable communication:** Eye-tracking devices, communication boards, Alexa/voice-controlled devices

â€¢ **Maintain connections:** Video calls with family and friends, visits when possible

questions.question: What is the two-person approach for emergencies?
questions.answer:
**Person 1 (Primary):**
â€¢ Start Ambu immediately
â€¢ Talk to PALS and get feedback
â€¢ Perform suction and nebulization
â€¢ Stay calm and focused on PALS

**Person 2 (Support):**
â€¢ Check all equipment connections
â€¢ Prepare supplies (catheters, NS)
â€¢ Monitor pulse oximeter
â€¢ Call for help if needed

**Why This Matters:** One person focuses on PALS while another ensures everything is ready. Reduces panic and mistakes.

**Even If Alone:** Start Ambu first (most important), then assess and act.

**Practice:** Train both caregivers on both roles BEFORE an emergency happens.

key_principles: Involve PALS in all decisions - they understand their body best
Prevention beats cure - regular nebulization, hydration, position changes prevent emergencies
Ambu is your best friend - when in doubt, give Ambu
Have backups for EVERYTHING critical - BiPAP, suction, power
Document and learn - every PALS is different
Take care of yourself - caregiver health matters
You are not alone - community is here to support you 24/7
Plan ahead - don't wait for emergencies to arrange equipment
Start interventions early - BiPAP, PEG work better before crisis
Focus on quality of life - many PALS live 5, 8, even 10+ years with good care
